With her dragons, she is the most powerful person in the world - she is larger than life, almost god-like, which the show reinforces when the Dothraki falls to their knees in worship after she burns the Dosh Khaleen in season 6 (x). It is fascinating that Clapton also relates the use of white with Daenerys feeling like she has a divine right (to what she wants) and that she is beyond question, which is an incredibly dangerous thing for a ruler to think. 

When it comes to Daenerys, white is connected to her being powerful, untouchable, remote and almost god-like.

This certainly sounds very impressive but all of these things signals a person that is both lonely and too powerful for her own good. Being extraordinary and god-like might sound nice but it also removes her from the rest of humanity.

Daenerys wears darker colours in season 6 and most of season 7 - so it is note-worthy when she switches back to white in the middle of season 7 when she flies north of the Wall wearing a show-stopping white fur coat. It is, as mentioned before, a warrior look - but it is also a look connected to her infatuation with Jon:

“It was the first time that I could remember that Dany had put herself in danger that is not necessarily for personal gain, so the white was this sense of purity,” said costume designer Clapton (a three-time Emmy winner for “Game of Thrones” and last year’s winner for “The Crown”). “It had an honesty to it…she has fallen in love with Jon.” (Michele Clapton, IndieWire)

Yet even here Dany can’t escape the dehumanizing effect of the way that Clapton uses white in her costumes:

Clapton equated the visual importance of Dany’s white coat with mythology. “I wanted to create this powerful image of her descending like an Angel to save these men from imminent death,” she said. (Michele Clapton, IndieWire)

The visual effect was dazzling with the pale, silver-haired woman wearing pure white in a landscape of snow and ice. 

She looks ethereal - but not very human either - and the colour white is indeed very ambiguous in relation to Dany’s narrative arc as Clapton’s comments reveals. 

The promotional material reveals that Daenerys retains the white in some of her new costumes - but with one very important difference: the addition of the colour red, which becomes very conspicuous when compared to the white.

Red is one of the traditional colours of House Targaryen and Clapton has withheld it until season 7 for narrative reasons. 

“This season seemed to be the right time for Daenerys to start to embrace the shape and colours of her house,” Clapton told HuffPost in an email. “She is in touching distance of her desired place … so I liked this flowering, this visual expression of her growing confidence that she could maybe take the throne.” (Michele Clapton, Huffpost)

However, Clapton really uses red in a very loaded way when it comes to Dany because it not just her House colour, it is also a outward sign of her hunger for power in the form of the Iron Throne. This is an ambition that she adopted from her brother Viserys, so when Dany wear’s red it also refers to her late brother:

“When we see her now, she’s starting to wear the colors of her brother. What does that say about her?“ (Michele Clapton, Winter Is Coming - on Dany’s season 8 costume) 

So it is interesting that the colour red has become so much more prominent in her season 8 costumes, especially since she’s seemingly put her ambition on hold to help Jon Snow save the world. The red is even more noticeable in these three new costumes than it was in her season 7 costumes where it was much more discreetly used.

All her new costumes are lined in red, their decorative elements are red and her accessories are red. Not only are there more red elements than in her season 7 costumes, the colour itself has become much more vivid, which is demonstrated in the edit above. The image to the right is an unfiltered BTS photo whereas the one to the left is from the EW photo shoot and has thus been through Photoshop. Just notice how vivid the red is in the unedited/unfiltered pic! Furthermore, the effect of the vivid red gloves is a bit unnerving since it makes one think of bloody hands, just like the red stripes in the white fur coat has an eerie “blood on snow” effect. @lostlittlesatellites suggests that in Dany uses red in her season 8 costumes as a way to display authority since it is linked to her Targaryen identity, which is the very basis of her pursuit of power over Westeros. Daenerys isn’t the only character where red signals a desire for power.

Red/Gold (Cersei)

Cersei has worn black since Joffrey was killed in season 4 - that is a long time, so imagine my excitement when one of her new costumes turns out to be made from red velvet! Cersei is shedding her mourning clothes and returning to her Lannister roots, wearing red and gold.

When it comes to Cersei, the colour red has always been connected to two things: her identity as a Lannister and her struggle for power.

“As the story progresses, for instance, Cersei, when we first saw her, she was actually not terribly often in red. And then as she asserts her power, she became very bright red, very Lannister. And then it went to more of a blood-red, and then it went to black, which shows she’s in mourning for her children.” (Michele Clapton, BuzzFeed)

She doesn’t really start to wear red in a big way until season 2 when she’s finally free of her abusive husband and where she’s trying to grab some power for herself, to have a hand in steering the course of the realm. When her power begins to wane, then the red recedes from her costumes:

“Cersei is pulling back a little bit. She’s not the powerhouse that she was and I wanted her to be slightly quieter. She’s still very beautiful, but just not rocking the red so much. I think she can see her power is abating.” (Michele Clapton)

When she took the Iron Throne at the end of season 6, Cersei was perhaps the most powerful she’s ever been - but she’s lost all her children so even when she’s achieved power, she’s still in the black of mourning. The trailer showed us that she has a black costume, which she’ll most likely wear in the early episodes, so I’m very curious as to when Cersei switches back to the Lannister-red, which signals power. 

A lot of this analysis is speculative because we don’t know the context of these costumes. When are they going to be worn? How do they fit with all the new costumes for each character? It is especially frustrating to speculate about Sansa’s leather dress because this is the only new costume of hers that they’ve released images of. We’ve gotten more material about Dany and Cersei’s new costumes - but so little about how Clapton is going to shape Sansa’s look in this final season.

(GIF not mine)
trail.content_abstract:
I’m a big fan of Michele Clapton’s work on Game of Thrones, so I am always excited when the promotional material gives us a sneak peek at some of the new costumes. This year, the excitement was even bigger because Sophie Turner had let slip that Sansa’s would be wearing armour in the final season of the show (x). However, the promotional photos revealed a costume that isn’t actual armour but more of a warrior look in a symbolic sense, which fits well with another thing Turner said about Sansa’s arc in the last season:

“We the idea of it being very protective and she buttons herself up,” Turner says. “I wanted her to have a bit of armor and be a bit more warrior like. She’s like the warrior of Winterfell.” (Sophie Turner, EW)

This battle dress of black leather is the only one of Sansa’s new costumes that we’ve gotten a preview of so far - whereas we’ve gotten a look at two new costumes for Cersei and three for Daenerys. 

This new costume does have a warrior look. In Part 1 of this series of essays, I took a closer look at the texture of this costume, especially in relation to the leather armour of House Tully. In Part 2, I discussed how this textured leather dress evokes a couple of Sansa’s earlier costumes as well as the similarities and differences it has with Cersei’s iconic coronation dress, which is also made of black leather. In this final post, I’ll explore how Sansa’s new leather costume might function both as an equivalent to and a juxtaposition of the warrior look that Daenerys debuted in season 7 and carries over into season 8.

summary: A Game of Thrones reading
body:
A Game of Thrones reading

I’m rereading the first Game of thrones book and I noticed something so cool. I was reading Eddards chapter as he was musing on the revelation that Joffrey was not Roberts son. He says “someday when Sansa was grown, he would have to tell her how she had made it all come clear to him. He’s not the least bit like that old drunken king, she had declared, angry and unknowing and the simple truth of it had twisted inside him, cold as death.” Sansa has always been able to see the truth. For as much as people want to make fun of her for believing in fairytales, it’s because she sees the truth all too well. We see it again when (show reference) she’s watching the ships with Shae and she scolds her for being realistic about their destination claiming “the truth is always either terrible or boring” then again when she is talking to the Queen Cersei and Cersei tells her to make the people fear her yet Sansa knows that love is a surer route to their hearts and she vows if she’s ever Queen she will make them love her.

Perhaps these are just ramblings of a Sansa fan so if you don’t agree that’s fine but I thought it was worth noting.

summary: The fact that antis are now saying Kit and Sophie filmed "fake scenes" together is nuts. You don't have to ship them but please...
body: The fact that antis are now saying Kit and Sophie filmed “fake scenes” together is nuts. You don’t have to ship them but please stop with that crap. Jon and Sansa’s relationship will obviously be one of the most important ones regardless, so stop trying to make them nothing when we obviously know that’s not true. D&D didn’t build their relationship for the last 3 seasons for them to not be important in each other‘s lives.

body:
things sansa stans have said that’s now canon:

  • jon won’t be forgiven for kneeling
  • dany won’t be accepted by the northern and vale lords
  • jon and arya won’t have a warm reunion
  • sansa will clash with dany
  • the battle against the night king happens early
  • sansa isn’t dying and she’s getting a good ending
  • jon won’t be happy to learn that his father is rhaegar

and we have had interviews and actual footage proving this.

things we’ve speculated about that haven’t been confirmed yet:

  • dany isn’t pregnant
  • bran is the key to winning
  • sam won’t be happy to hear half his family is dead
  • dark dany is happening
  • jaime isn’t going to pledge himself to dany
  • tyrion will betray dany
  • jorah will choose the north over dany

this is because we actually analyse the show instead of relying on headcanons

summary: The interview where the person asks if Arya or Sansa is the most creative, and the fact that Sophie Turner and Maisie Williams...
body: The interview where the person asks if Arya or Sansa is the most creative, and the fact that Sophie Turner and Maisie Williams answer Arya almost immediately makes me sad. Not because of the choice itself though. That doesn’t bother me. I mean in the show, Arya has found pretty innovative ways to survive and deal with her enemies, and I’m not trying to take anything from her, but what makes me sad it’s that this immediate answer is a pretty strong reminder of just how little the show did with Sansa’s proficiencies in the art department. She could write poems, play instruments, sing and dance. Not only did she do these things, but she enjoyed and was very good at doing these things. She was also very creative in the sense that she would often make up very elaborate lies in order to survive a certain situation, and when it came the time for her to become Alayne Stone, she did not only have a lot of ideas of the possible background of her character but she would add little details to her character as she became more immersed in that identity. I really wished the showrunners bothered to adapt that aspect of her character.

summary: once again, the antis continue to astound me with the absolute bullshit they can come up with. it appears that the got fandom...
body:
once again, the antis continue to astound me with the absolute bullshit they can come up with. it appears that the got fandom has been ‘held hostage’ by the sansa stans. stans who are apparently mostly white and twisting narratives to promote ‘false claims’ of racism and sexism.

what
the
actual
fuck

i love how d stans have the motherfucking audacity to lecture us about racism like they even know what the fuck it is they’re talking about. i mean, imagine talking to us about racism when when your fave has scenes where:

  • she’s crowd-surfing on poc slaves like she’s the second coming of Christ Himself
  • she’s burning down the holy temple of pocs
  • is the one to lecture pocs on how they should be led when she’s not even one of them

i mean, the fucking CAUCASITY!

a word of advice? don’t talk to us about racism when your fave’s the living, breathing embodiment of white saviour, and you refuse to call out those aspects of her arc.

and as to false claims of sexism…

you…you really don’t venture into the got fandom, have you?

sansa stark can’t sneeze without any of you ppl criticizing her. if it’s not for the fact that she doesn’t wield a sword like arya, doesn’t have magical powers like bran or d/ny, she’s either irrelevant, can’t fight, useless, power-hungry, bitch, stupid, weak, responsivle for ned’s death (seven fucking hells), is rude to jon, cold or frigid. she’s either mocked for being a victim, hated for being a victim, ppl either only like her when she’s a victim, or blamed for becoming a victim.

ppl blame her for trusting lf in s5, blame her for marrying ramsay, blame her for being r*ped by ramsay…

i just….

are you for fucking real?!

if it’s one word i can think of when it comes to the way ppl talk about sansa in this shit-hole of a fandom, it’s sexist. i’m not sorry that us defending her makes you feel like you’re being held hostage.

if you’re gonna make a post about about something, know what the fuck it is you’re talking about before embarassing yourself.

unsincerely, a black woman who stans sansa stark

and as to false claims of sexism…

you…you really don’t venture into the got fandom, have you?

sansa stark can’t sneeze without any of you ppl criticizing her. if it’s not for the fact that she doesn’t wield a sword like arya, doesn’t have magical powers like bran or d/ny, she’s either irrelevant, can’t fight, useless, power-hungry, bitch, stupid, weak, responsivle for ned’s death (seven fucking hells), is rude to jon, cold or frigid. she’s either mocked for being a victim, hated for being a victim, ppl either only like her when she’s a victim, or blamed for becoming a victim.

ppl blame her for trusting lf in s5, blame her for marrying ramsay, blame her for being r*ped by ramsay…

i just….

are you for fucking real?!

if it’s one word i can think of when it comes to the way ppl talk about sansa in this shit-hole of a fandom, it’s sexist. i’m not sorry that us defending her makes you feel like you’re being held hostage.

if you’re gonna make a post about about something, know what the fuck it is you’re talking about before embarassing yourself.

unsincerely, a black woman who stans sansa stark

summary:
there was once a boy who loved. no. stop.
start over.
there was once a girl who dreamed of bigger and brighter things and isn’t...
body:
there was once a boy who loved. no. stop.

start over.

there was once a girl who dreamed of bigger and brighter things and isn’t that how every story goes?

but here it is:

in the midst of summer, the sun shines brightly among the clear blue skies. lush green trees surround the cool lake, waves rippling across.

two girls sit on a rickety wooden bench in the warm sun, bodies barely brushing each other. red hair spills forth down her back, eyes squinting against the vivid landscape as she tosses a pebble ahead.

the pebbles barely skips and the girl with the hair of platinum blonde hair laughs and laughs.

in another world, [she] dany was the mother of dragons, and held onto [her] sansa - the wolf who had valiantly united them.

in this world, they are same and so very different with years of friendship, nostalgia, and love between them.

sansa smiles with a quirk of her lips, delighted by her laughter as her fingers brush against dany’s in the next moment.

in every world, there’s a sansa and a dany in love.

photo: https://pin.it/466vz6ajahsxjg

Rebecca & Rosalie | Characters | Pinterest

summary: Dance of the dragons 2.0
body:
Dance of the dragons 2.0

In the books a theory was it would have been between aegon (fake aegon) and Dany.

Faegony just invaded Westeros and it was seeming like at some point Dany and him would clash with him having a larger army etc.

But considering the events in the show we know the real Aegon is Jon so what does this mean for Jon and Dany.

If Jon fights for the throne it would have to be for a reason. Dany wants it because it’s the power she fought for for so long. If Jon fights it it has to be for Duty.

We know that the Baratheon line was born from dragon blood. A bastard targaryen birth . So Gendry is not safe. From melisandre or from Dany who knows

The first Daenerys targaryen died from shivers. A plague took. So dany cant die from fire but from ice.

So dance of dragons was done out of political reasons what would 2.0 be from?

It is possible that Dany would , at some point , ignore advisement and rush to overthrow Cersei proving to be a threat to thousands of lives?

Would Jon make a deal with Cersei for the greater good creating bad blood between him and Dany?

What about Dorne? Will Dany leave to get the help of Dorne on her side. And Jon will have Cersei on his side ?

But bottom line the possibility of Dance of the Dragons 2.0 cannot be ignored.

summary: I just want to say that stanning Sansa Stark from the very beginning was the rightest thing i have done in my life... we...
body: I just want to say that stanning Sansa Stark from the very beginning was the rightest thing i have done in my life… we suffered the hatred against our fav character. But in the end we were right/we’ll be right…Understanding her importance also made us to understand the series, other characters and where the series is going. Because we weren’t blinded by the hate for a little girl. Great thanks to the Sansa Fandom.
